story: The international pariah Communist dictator Ceausescu visited the UK in 1978 for four days.The Queen ostensibly welcomed the Romanian leader at London&rsquos Victoria Station and was later pictured sitting beside him in a state Landau carriage to Buckingham PalaceThe honour of riding in the Queen&rsquos carriage is expected as part of a full state visit but according to royal author Robert Hardman who wrote &lsquoOur Queen, the monarch tried to avoid meeting him other than when necessary.While walking her dogs in the Palace gardens, the Queen spotted Ceausescu and his wife Elena heading in her direction.                Lady Colin Campbell under fire for lurid claims about Queen and PhilipThe Queen decided the best course of action was to hide behind a bush rather than attempt polite conversation, Her Majesty told a lunch guest some years later, Mr Hardman said.Ceausescu and his wife were tried and convicted of economic sabotage and genocide in a trial lasting just one hour in 1989.The pair was immediately executed by firing squad.Ceausescu served concurrently as the general secretary of the Romanian Communist Party, the president of Romania and the president of the state council from 1974 to 1989.The Queen sitting beside Romanian leader Nicolae Ceausescu in a state Landau carriage (Image: )The internationally unpopular Communist dictator Ceausescu visited the Queen in 1978 (Image: )Before his trial in 1989, Ceausescu ordered his military forces to open fire on protesters killing and injuring dozens.The Queen over her 66 year reign has met with dozens of state leaders including Chinese President Xi Jinping, King Abdullah of Saudi Arabia, Russian President Vladimir Putin and former US president George W Bush.Next month Her Majesty will meet Donald Trump during his first official trip to the UK since he became US President, however, it will not be a full state visit.The latest pictures of Her Majesty the Queen.                    PA1 of 100Queen Elizabeth II attends a reception for 603 (City of Edinburgh) Squadron, Royal Auxiliary Air ForceA full state visit has been put off to a later following concerns of mass protests by critics of Mr Trump.Amnesty International has already announced &ldquothousands of its supporters will protest during his visit.The US President will be joined by his wife Melania Trump when he arrives on July 13.The Queen once hid behind a bush to avoid a guest, a royal author has said (Image: )

It would keep the flow of goods going.Officially known as the EU-Canada Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA), the agreement was signed in October 2016, after seven years of negotiation and ratification.Canada&rsquos CETA deal removes 99 percent of customs duties on European exports to Canada and vice versa.CETA also allows EU companies the opportunity to bid for public contracts in Canada.Canada is not obliged under CETA to pay into the EU budget, sign up to such as free movement, or abide by European Court of Justice (ECJ) rulings.

title: Brexit news UK EU latest Theresa May deal Galileo satellite programme
story: The Tory backbencher warned the European Union &ldquoit doesn&rsquot cut both ways after the Brussels bloc threatened to cut Britain out of the Galileo satellite programme despite a &pound1billion financial contribution to the project.The EU claimed Britain would no longer be allowed to collaborate and use the satellite system because of perceived security threats to the programme after Brexit.Speaking to Express from the Conservative Party Conference, Mr Bridgen said: &ldquoApparently, we are into it for about &pound1.2billion and it was a lot of our technology the whole project relies upon and at a whim the EU will say &lsquowell we don&rsquot want you to be involved in this&rsquo.&ldquoWell, the quid pro quo of that is the EU do want us to be involved in guaranteeing security of the European Union through our huge commitment to defence of Europe.                New BRITISHNESS TEST will demand migrants grasp British values                Leave campaigner reveals 'INTOLERABLE' racist abuse from Remainers&ldquoIt just really doesn&rsquot cut both ways. It&rsquos very difficult to see what concessions at all we have got from the EU during these negotiations.&ldquoIt appears to be more of a capitulation than a negotiation.Despite contributing around &pound1billion to the &pound8.5billion costs of the project, which when fully operational will rival the US government's Global Positioning System (GPS), Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier suggested the UK faces being cut off after leaving the bloc next year.The UK Space Agency announced in August the launch of a &pound92 billion feasibility study on an alternative system to Galileo.Brexit news: Andrew Bridgen said negotiations with EU have so far been a capitulation (Image: &bull)Prime Minister Theresa May said in a statement: We've been clear that the UK wants to remain involved in the EU&rsquos Galileo satellite programme.But we cannot be an &lsquoend user&rsquo, shut out from security discussions and contracts, and without critical information about the system&rsquos security.Use of something we are unable to rely on has little value, and we cannot justify paying towards that.She added: So unless we receive assurance that we can collaborate on a close basis in the future - like the close security partners we aspire to be - we are clear that we will withdraw UK support for Galileo and pursue our own sovereign satellite system.And this is not an idle threat to achieve our negotiating objectives.Additional reporting by Caitlin Collins and Thomas Hunt in Birmingham.

title: UK weather forecast storm leslie latest met office forecast
story: Tropical storm Leslie is feared to hit just as temperatures plunge whipping up Arctic gales and unleashing torrents of snow across swathes of the country.Furious winds, torrential rain and wintry downpours could plague the nation until the end of October sparking warnings of an early winter freeze.Leslie is currently strengthening in the Atlantic on her path towards America and is expected to have developed into a fully-fledged hurricane by tomorrow.Latest forecast charts show the churning vortex changing direction and hurtling northward towards Europe ahead of the weekend.UK meteorologists think its remnants could sweep towards Britain and Ireland at the end of next week stirring up a bout of unsettled weather.It could open the floodgates to a barrage of stormy low-pressure systems bringing a wet and windy start to the second half of autumn.Britain&rsquos weather is unlikely to settle down much before the end of October with falling temperatures bringing an increased risk of wintry conditions.Weather charts already show a colossal wave of powerful winds taking a swipe at the nation just before mid-month.The Weather Company&rsquos Sarah Satya Sammy said Leslie will remain in the mid-Atlantic for several days before heading towards Europe.                UK weather forecast: Britain set for COLDEST weekend for six months...                UK weather forecast: Hurricane-force Cyclone Leslie to hit BritainShe said: &ldquoTropical Storm Leslie is expected to slowly intensify into Hurricane Leslie between today and Wednesday.&ldquoPresently Leslie remains in a blocking pattern in the mid-Atlantic and is expected to linger in that general vicinity over the next week or so.&ldquoEarly indications are that Leslie will transition to extratropical and meander over the open waters of the central Atlantic through next week.&ldquoAs Leslie approaches Europe, toward the end of next week, it will initially affect Portugal as an extra-tropical low, before taking a more north-ward path, approaching Ireland by that Saturday.&ldquoThere is still quite a bit of uncertainty in this forecast.Government forecasters agree if the storm does end up coming towards Britain its impact will be felt towards the end of next week.Met Office chief meteorologist Andy Page said: &ldquoLeslie will likely strengthen to a hurricane as it moves over warmer waters with large swells affecting Bermuda and east coast of the United States and the Caribbean.&ldquoIt is likely to gradually weaken after this and move eastwards across the north Atlantic.&ldquoSome models suggest Leslie will track south of the UK while others suggest it may move close to the UK by the end of next week.UK weather forecast: Storm Leslie is set to batter Britain (Image:   WXCHARTS)Long-range experts say a barrage of storms could launch an attack on Britain from the middle of October bringing a sustained assault through the rest of the month.The UK Met Office this week confirmed a particularly active start to the Atlantic hurricane season has already spawned an unusually high number of storms.The Weather Company warned high pressure responsible for the current calm conditions is about to weaken allowing a more unsettled pattern to develop.A spokesman said: &ldquoWe are looking at a period of cooler-than-average temperatures across most of Europe, with persistently cool conditions for northwest Europe.&ldquoIt&rsquos likely to remain cool and become stormy through October as high pressure drifts away.A similar outlook has been given by the Met Office in its 30-day October forecast which warns a more choppy period of weather is likely to set in after next week.It states: &ldquoThe weather in the second half of October looks likely to be on the wet and windy side, though drier and brighter interludes are likely too.&ldquoGales are possible at times, particularly in the northwest.&ldquoTowards the end of the month, there is a chance of more settled weather developing again, particularly in the south, where night time fog and frosts would become more likely.&ldquoTemperatures will probably be generally colder than average by then, but with some short-lived milder interludes at times.UK weather forecast: Storm Leslie is set to batter Britain (Image: WX CHARTS)A dramatic change in the weather before the end of the month could come as a shock to the system as the nation braces for an early winter onslaught.Exacta Weather forecaster James Madden warned milder, settled conditions forecast over the coming days could eventually give way to a bombardment of winter storms.He said: &ldquoA final burst of summer could be in the offing around the middle of next week however the first snow of the season will not be too far behind.&ldquoAt least one or two major low-pressure systems will attempt to cause havoc on our weather patterns within this period, and this is most likely from mid-month onwards.&ldquoWe also expect at least one of these low-pressure systems to arrive under a colder airmass to the north of the country during the final third of October, and it is within this period that we could see the first significant snow of the season across higher ground in parts of Scotland and the north.UK weather forecast: Storm Leslie has unexpectedly shifted direction towards Britain (Image: NHC)Mild weather is set to continue across southern Britain until the end of this week when cooler air from the north will push temperatures slightly below average.Scotland and the north will remain cooler compared to the rest of the country thanks to a Polar Maritime airmass over the region, forecasters say.The Weather Company&rsquos Katie Greening said: &ldquoAtlantic air has moved into the UK bringing mild conditions although there will be rain patches over the north and the west.&ldquoTemperatures will lift two to four degrees above the seasonal average with highs reaching the low 20Cs this week.&ldquoIt will turn wet, windy and cloudy at the weekend and it is expected to turn much cooler with temperatures falling a few degrees below normal for the time of year.

story: Laughter and gasps filled the European Parliament in Strasbourg as Luke &lsquoMing&rsquo Flanagan, an Irish Independent MEP, bellowed &ldquowhere are you?.Mr Flanagan said the president failed to keep the promises made during his State of the Union speech in 2017, where he vowed to set out a clear plan for the future of the European Union until 2025.And, Mr Flanagan pointed out, he even failed to attend the full length of today&rsquos European Parliament plenary debate, which was vital preparation for a summit later this month where the Brexit deal could be signed off.The MEP for Roscommon&ndashSouth Leitrim said: &ldquoWhere is this white paper on the future of Europe?&nbsp                &rsquoWe will not backtrack by a MILLIMETRE!&rsquo Italy vows defiance vs EU                Blame Juncker! 'Ignorant' EU will be economically devastated by Brexit                The day Europe stabbed Britain in the back: Wild scenes in StrasbourgLuke Flanagan is an eurosceptic Irish MEP (Image: EU)Luke Flanagan MEP asked Mr Juncker why he didn't produce any White Paper on the future of the EU (Image: EU)The MEP said: &ldquoWe were meant to have a discussion about this, a debate, something that I think would have helped a couple of years ago in Britain and would have actually headed off Brexit.&ldquoWe also had a series of reflection papers which were meant to be discussed.&ldquoWe were also meant to have a series of debate around Europe.&ldquoMr Juncker came in here and talked us about varying numbers, they didn&rsquot add up.&nbspLuke Flanagan MEP attended the monthly EU Parliament plenary session (Image: EU)&ldquoOn the Commission blurb they talked about this process and they said it will help decide on the course of action to be ruled out in time of the MEP election in 2019.However, Mr Flanagan said, the Commission never presented these White Paper, leaving MEP and European citizens in the dark about the upcoming crucial vote, taking place in May 2019.European Parliament plenary sessions take place once a month and it last each time for four days, with MEP voting on EU legislation and adopting specific positions on political issues.&nbsp&nbsp

title: Typhoon Kong rey Hurricane Walaka Pacific Category 5 cyclone
story: At one point yesterday both were Category-5-equivalent in strength, the first time the planet has hosted two storms of the strength at the same time in over 10 years.In the western Pacific super typhoon Kong-rey is moving in a north-westerly direction, and is expected to smash into south Korea towards the end of the week.Kong-ey&rsquos weakened remnant will then head on towards Japan.Kong-rey is currently the equivalent of a Category 4 Atlantic hurricane.                Typhoon Kong-rey: Potential threat to life as 175mph storm nears Ja...                Super Typhoon Kong Rey: NASA releases infrared image of storm buildingIt has sustained winds of 155 miles per hour and gusts of up to 190 miles per hour.However, the storm is projected to weaken over the next few days, to wind speeds of around 85 miles per hour before it hits into South Korea.For a period yesterday Kong-rey was a Category 5 equivalent storm, with sustained winds speeds of over 157 miles per hour.For the first time since 2005 two storms of this strength were active at the same time.Super Typhoon Kong-rey (left) and Hurricane Walaka (right)  (Image: WXCHARTS)Kong-rey is currently the equivalent of a Category 4 Atlantic hurricane (Image: EPA )The second is Hurricane Walaka, which is racing across the Pacific northeast.It is currently located around 400 miles to the west of Honolulu.Walaka&rsquos strength has since fallen slightly, down to Category 4.However with sustained wind speeds of 150 miles per hour it remains just seven miles per hour below the Category 5 threshold.                Taiwan could take a DIRECT HIT from Super Typhoon Kong-reyTyphoon Trami caused hit Japan last week  (Image: EPA)Four workers have been evacuated by the US Coast Guard ahead of the storm.In a press release Captain Robert Hendrickson of the Coast Guard said: &ldquoJohnston Atoll is extremely remote and difficult to reach.&ldquoOur resources place us in a position to lend assistance to our partners within the US Fish and Wildlife Service and we are glad to help.&ldquoWe encourage anyone operating in the Pacific to keep an eye on the weather as this storm moves toward the Northwest Hawaiian Islands.

title: brexit no deal theresa may dominic raab
story: If we end up quitting the EU without a deal, more than million British passports are likely to be useless on the continent.Ministers today published documents confirming that in a No Deal scenario, British people will need to have a passport which is valid for at least six monthsthey want to visit the EU.And they urged anyone who might be affected to act quickly - because there is likely to be a massive rush of Brits trying to renew their documents.The revelation came in a dossier of  contingency notices designed to show the Government is prepared for the potential collapse of talks with Brussels.The documents show:The documents warn that without a deal ensuring British citizens have access to the continent, UK travellers will be treated the same way as those from outside the EU.That means that they wont be able to enter the borderless Schengen zone unless their passport is valid for at least six months from the date of entry.Anyone whose passport expires within the next year is therefore at risk of being shut out from the EU from March next year and should apply for new documents, the Government warned.They said: If you are planning travel after  March , and your passport will be affected by the new validity rules, we recommend you consider renewing your passport soon to avoid any delay, as the passport issuing service can get busy, especially in the spring.The warning is estimated to affect at least million Brits - because around  per cent of the population is believed to hold a passport, and of those roughly  per cent will be in their last six months.There could also be problems for British tourists hoping to drive to the continent or rent a car on holiday.Under No Deal, UK driving licences would no longer be valid in the EU so holidaymakers would need to buy an international driving permit, available at the Post Office for £..The Government said: You may be turned away at the border or face other enforcement action, for example fines,you don’t have the correct IDP.Ministers have already acted to head off the threat of phone firms hiking up roaming charges once we are no longer bound by the EU rules which outlaw them.They have agreed with O, Vodafone, EE and Three that none of the largest companies will introduce new fees - though customers of smaller firms may still face a price rise.One unexpected effect of No Deal could be that Britain gets less warning of space debris falling to Earth thanks to the end of an information-sharing deal with Europe.Companies which export so-called non-harmonised goods - items such as furniture, bicycles and cooking tools which are governed by national rules rather than EU-wide regulations - may need new licences to continue selling them into Europe under a No Deal scenario.And shipping firms could be hit by additional red tape, the documents added.But ministers have also taken actions to minimise the disruption of a No Deal Brexit - such as saying we will continue to observe EU rules on the environment no matter what the outcome of Brexit talks.The right to travel freely between Britain and Ireland will continue eventhere is no deal, under the rule of the Common Travel Area.And Irish citizens will “continue to enjoy the reciprocal rights” to live in the UK, as well as “work, study and vote, [and get] access to social welfare benefits and health services”.The Home Office says this will be the same for British citizens in Ireland.Shadow Brexit Secretary Keir Starmer rubbished todays announcements, saying: “The only reason the Government is talking about No Deal is because the Tory civil war on Europe prevents the Prime Minister from negotiating a good deal.And pro-EU MP David Lammy, a backer of the Best for Britain campaign, said: As these papers show, a No Deal Brexit will not only kneecap the British economy, disproportionately hurting the poorest. It will also make le more dficult in innumerable ways - affecting driving licences, passports and phone bills.Today is just a cynical ploy by the Government to make whatever pathetic little deal they bring back from Brussels look less bad in comparison.Emmanuel Macrons Europe minister warned that Eurostar trains and planes from Britain will be turned away from France in the event of a No Deal Brexit.In comments that came just an hour after the Government papers were published, Nathalie Loiseau insisted it was not Le Project Fear to warn of travel chaos that but it “would happen – among other examples”.Asked about the issue following a speech in London, she said: This is the reason we need to prepare for a No Deal because we cannot wake up and say to our citizens and businesses we thought it would never happen so we are not ready.Cabinet ministers met this morning to discuss the No Deal contingency plans which are designed to ensure Britain is ready for the possible collapse of talks with Brussels.Speaking before the plans were published, Dominic Raab warned rebel MPs they will have no choice but to back Theresa May - or risk Brexit chaos.He said Brexit rebels would have to be responsible and rubbished the idea they can force through an alternative plan by next March.Tory MPs from all sides of the Brexit ide have called for the PM to chuck her proposals set out at Chequers.But the Brexit Secretary said it would be impossible to replace Mrs Mays blueprint with a dferent type of trade deal.He told the BBCs Today programme: When push comes to shove it will be a binary choice between the deal we bring back and No Deal, and I think that will focus minds.Colleagues will look at the choices theyve got and theyve got to be responsible for that.During the interview he also hit out at firms such as John Lewis which blame their economic troubles on Brexit.Mr Raab said: I think there will be the temptation from some businesses that arent doing so well to blame Brexit and I think thats a mistake.He confirmed that we wont pay a £billion orce billwe dont manage to secure a withdrawal agreement.Mr Raab said: Its not a threat, its statement of fact as part of our No Deal planning.We would be mindful of our strict legal obligations, but the amount and the phased way it is set out in the withdrawal agreement would fall away because there would be no deal.DOZENS of Brexit-backing Tory MPs are furious with Theresa Mays Chequers plan, which would see Britain following EU rules for goods even after weve left.They have launched a huge campaign to persuade the PM to drop her proposals and replace them with a looser free-trade deal.Some hardliners are even trying to ditch Mrs May altogether - convinced that only a Brexit true believer can truly carry out the will of the people.But both efforts are massively complicated by the fact that we have just six months before Britain officially leaves the EU.Senior Brexiteers are in despair about the leadership chatter, warning thatthe PM was forced out Remainers would seize the opportunity to delay or even overturn Brexit.And as Dominic Raab points out today, the short timeline makes it dficult for any plan other than Mrs Mays to take shape.If Britain and the EU do thrash out a withdrawal deal later this year, it will almost certainly be based on the PMs Chequers deal.MPs will have a straight choice when it comes to a Commons vote - support the deal as it stands, or back No Deal.Ministers are gambling that enough Tories will lose their nerve and vote with the Government to outnumber the rebels who team up with Jeremy Corbyn to try and defeat it.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: karren brady the apprentice launch slippery excuses
story: Sixteen budding entrepreneurs battling it out to win £k of Lord Sugar’s own money as an investment to start their own business.Alan goes into partnership with the winner — and that’s where Claude Littner and I come in.We are there to make sure he chooses the right person, by watching what happens when the contestants are out on tasks.People know it’s that time of year when they see Claude and I out on the streets with a notepad, pen and film crew.We don’t mentor, we don’t coach or give any guidance, we simply watch what unfolds. And what is amazing to me is how often people try to wriggle out of things and deny a decision they made, in a bid to stay in the process. So when they sit in the boardroom saying, “I didn’t . . . ” we can say, “Oh yes you did . . . ”Some people ask mecertain scenes are staged, but the show is unique in that there are no retakes, there is no setting up of scenes and no trying to find the comedy moment — they just come naturally.All of Alan’s jokes come naturally, too. There is no script, no autocue, it happens as it happens.Luckily, we get on very well — Claude, Alan and I. So much so that we all went on holiday together this year.We’re all quite similar, we have all been married for a long time and we all share the same family values.It makes us a watertight team, although we each bring something dferent to the table.But, parking that for a moment, The Apprentice is also top-notch entertainment — this series more than ever. What’s great about the first episode is that the contestants, all of whom talk the talk about how fantastic they are, are thrown into the deep end with a task that’s designed to test their logic.They are sent on what is a bit like a treasure hunt, in Malta, armed only with a map and some euros.This task is all about logistics, negotiation and identying, and let’s say it doesn’t end well.It turns out that, unfortunately, logic is not something all the contestants are in possession of.During this series we will travel all over the country, including to Glasgow to sell emerging artists’ work to the unsuspecting public.When I say that task was more challenging than ever, I’m referring partly to the challenge of actually getting to Glasgow because it was during the storms. Remember them Turbulence was an under-statement. On the flight there, I was gritting my teeth and grabbing on to Claude like there was no tomorrow.One thing I love about the show is that there are equal numbers of men and women, and they are on a level playing field.Let’s face it, the same cannot be said out there in the “real” world.One thing I’ve been reflecting on over the course of my time on The Apprentice is how much things have changed for women in business since I started out.When I was having my kids  years ago, the very notion of “work-le balance” didn’t exist. But I’m pleased to say that working women aren’t trying to Have It All any more, and the days are gone when women feel the need to keep quiet about having kids at work.Women are now more able to demand flexible working and feel entitled to have time off for, say, ante-natal classes.More “mumpreneurs” are starting their own businesses. Still, you rarely catch working mothers using childcare as a reason for being absent from work — while men, I’ve noticed, almost get points for doing so.And it is still the case that working mothers and women working flexibly are less likely to be promoted.So I don’t quite agree with Ann Widdecombe, the former Tory MP, who wrote this week that women today have “never had it so good” yet still “whinge” about inequality.Because while it might be true that things have changed for the better, most CEOs are still male.Women might never have had it so good but it’s still not good enough — and it’s not “whingeing” to point that out.HONESTLY, watching Jeremy Corbyn forgetting Labour’s six tests for a Brexit deal, when interviewed by the BBC’s Laura Kuenssberg, was like watching a hapless buffoon.No wonder he got two Es at A-level.This is the leader of the party that makes it up as it goes along – buying votes, promising everyone everything . . . and delivering absoutely nothing.As Margaret Thatcher said, The problem with socialism is that you eventually run out of other people’s money.HERE, The Apprentice star Karren picks out some highlights to look forward to during the show’s new season . . .Wyatt said: “Bill Cosby is doing great . . . Mr Cosby knows that God is watching over him . . . he knows that these are lies.“They persecuted Jesus and look what happened . . .  I’m not saying Mr Cosby is Jesus, but we know what this country has done to black men for centuries.”Just to be clear, Cosby’s conviction has nothing to do with race.The man is accused of rape and drug-facilitated sexual assault, by an astonishing  women . . . of all races and ages including some as young as .He has finally been put in prison and his victims have justice. He is a vile rapist, a violent sexual predator.His sentence is based on his crimes, not his colour.Unlike Cosby – a “disgusting sexual deviant” according to one of his victims – Jesus was innocent of the crimes laid against him.Cosby, meanwhile, has admitted to giving sedatives to young women in order to have sex with them.In short, Cosby admits his crimes, the jury find him guilty and the judge sentences him.Attempts to make this out as a racial issue are simply ridiculous.I KNOW it’s hard for men to face up to losing their hair, but someone needs to tell David Beckham that by far the best approach when it happens is . . . acceptance.But, judging from the photos of him looking a bit like a smiling Brillo pad this week that is not the route he is taking.David,you are reading this, you are a handsome man and no one caresyou have a thick head of hair or not – please don’t turn into Shane Warne.I guess the reality star has yet to realise no one is forcing her to go out.She just needs to learn the power of saying no.In the past, I had a dreadful habit of saying yes to an engagement when I meant no, then spent days trying to think of ways to get out of it.I completely changed my le when I decided to simply things by saying yes to an invitation when I wanted to go – and no when I didn’t.IT’S hard to believe not only that West Midlands Police are allowing “thrill-seekers” to spend Halloween in a cell used by serial murderer Fred West – but that they are charging them £ to do so.Offering this “spooky ghost hunt” at the notorious Steelhouse Lane cells in Birmingham is in very poor taste – so disrespectful of West’s victims, including his daughter who is a surviving casualty of his and is clearly still suffering every day.No doubt the relatives of those West murdered still suffer every day, too.So the fact that a stay in his old prison cell is being offered as Halloween entertainment is positively ghoulish.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: theresa may brave brexit vote
story: In the largest vote ever recorded in Britain, we chose to leave the Brussels racket.And as she reveals in our exclusive interview, Theresa May is determined to tell the world that we are getting out, no s, no buts.Tory Conference this week will be testy. There remain serious splits in the party over Brexit but on one thing they must be united: nothing can imperil our exit.But while the PM is right that a second referendum is for the birds, the country is constantly holding a referendum on her leadership.On domestic issues it is Labour that seems to have an answer to everything — eventhose easy solutions rely on made-up money and would be disastrous in practice.Governments cannot just promise the world in airy-fairy speeches but, faced with an Opposition full of empty promises, the Tories must be radical.They cannot just deliver watered-down versions of whatever Jeremy Corbyn has cooked up.There are plenty of brains in the Tory party. Let’s hear their ideas and a real vision of what Britain can be.IT is disgraceful that major food stores are exploiting a legal loophole to avoid showing ingredients on packaging.Teenager Natasha Ednan-Laperouse’s death should serve as a warning of how dangerous this practice is.The law states that when food is prepared onsite, ingredients labelling is not necessary. It is designed to protect small, independent stores.But our investigation today reveals large chains have not learnt from this avoidable tragedy.Pret a Manger was warned nine times about the dangers of sesame seed in its artisan baguettes and yet it continues to sell items without allergy warnings.Now Natasha’s mother Tanya has challenged the chain to lobby for a change in our labelling laws.And, hopefully, stop other parents having to suffer such a terrible loss.BON appétit, M’luds. You’re scoffing and quaffing grub and booze to the tune of £, A DAY and WE’RE footing the bill.The House of Lords, which is filled with political cronies and gloried lobbyists,represents the very worst of Whitehall’s snouts-in-the-trough culture.The sooner we have an elected House with a few handpicked specialists, the better.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: theresa may chequers brexit conservative conference boris johsnon
story: As the Tory conference started in Birmingham yesterday, the PM gave angry delegates hope by hinting there was “flexibility”.Meanwhile, Tories on all sides of the Brexit debate rallied round her after Boris Johnson launched his most personal attack yet.Marking the start of the Tories’ choppy annual conference in Birmingham, the under fire party leader told BBC’s Andrew Marr Show that a free trade deal is “at the heart of Chequers”.She also refused to rule out further fudges with the EU despite being asked to five separate times.And behind closed doors, Mrs May gave angry Tory delegates hope by saying there will be “flexibility” with Chequers in the last few weeks of negotiations.During a National Convention meeting with regional party bosses, The Sun has learned that the PM also conceded for the first time that her full plan to keep to the EU’s rules on goods and collect its customs tarfs has been knocked back by EU bosses.But “aspects of it will still work”, Mrs May told them.The key concessions came as senior Tories on all sides of the Brexit ide lashed out at Boris after the former Foreign Secretary issued his most personal attack on the PM yet.The mop haired senior Tory branded her Chequers plan for a softer Brexit “deranged”, and questioned whether she really believes in exiting the EU at all.That left Mrs May being forced to insist: I do believe in Brexit.But a long list of senior party figures seized on Boris’s latest diatribe in a Sunday newspaper to accuse him of attention seeking,Former Brexit Secretary and fellow Leave campaigner David Davis attacked Boris for coming up with “good headlines not good policies”.Scots Tory leader Ruth Davidson accused Boris of hypocrisy, branding it “strange” he is attacking Mrs May’s Northern Ireland backstop pledge having previously heaped praise on her for it when he was in the Cabinet.And in the more caustic comments of all, and TV celebrity Lord Digby Jones leaped on Boris for saying f*** business’.The former business minister told the party faithful from the conference patfrom: It showed him up to be the irrelevant and offensive person he really is.The Sun can also reveal a group of Tory MPs who have formed an ‘Anyone But Boris’ campaign to frustrate any leadership bid intend to boo Mr Johnson at a conference rally he will headline on Tuesday.One Tory minister said: “Several colleagues have said they are going to give Boris a taste of their own medicine and turn up to boo him.“He won’t be very happy at the idea that some of us are getting very fed up with his antics.”The backlash came as three dferent polls also yesterday revealed Mrs May is still liked by more voters than Boris.If the election was a two way race, a BMG Research poll for HuffPost UK found % backed Jeremy Corbyn versus % who supported Boris.But in answer to the same question comparing Mrs May and Mr Corbyn, the PM came out on top by % to %.Meanwhile, Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt warned Brussels would stir Britain’s “Dunkirk spirit”it forced a bad deal on Mrs May.He told The : “If President Macron thinks we will come crawling back to the club in a few years’ time, it is a profound misreading of our character.”In what was seen as the first of a series of pitches at the four day conference to succeed Mrs May, Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt compared the EU to the Soviet Union yesterday for treating Britain as a prisoner it won’t allow to leave.Remainer-turned-Brexiteer Mr Hunt told the hall: “What happened to the confidence and ideals of the European dream  The EU was set up to protect freedom.“It was the Soviet Union that stopped people leaving.Mr Hunt also issued a plea for warring Tory factions to come together and end their Brexit civil war.He added: “We can only unite the countrywe are united ourselves. In Parliament. In the Government. And in the Cabinet”.Meanwhile hardline backbench Tory Brexiteers put on a concerted show of strength last night hinting they could oust the PMshe did not change her Chequers plan.Boris’s close ally Conor Burns took direct aim, warning: I say to the Prime Minister - we dont want to change you, we want you to change the policy of Chequers.And he urged her to please, please adopt a Canada style trade deal instead, suggesting the affection he held for the PM was at breaking point.And he was backed at the Brexit Central website rally by Jacob Rees Mogg, who said Chequers was “not only a dying duck in a thunderstorm, it’s the deadest dying duck in a thunderstorm.And he blasted campaigners for a so-called Peoples Vote, comparing them to Chinese communist and Libyan tyrant Gaddafi.He said: Once you put peoples in the title it is not true, it is about the elite, about those in charge and we should be very careful about that.A former Defence Minister also accused the PM of behaving like scheming Italian prince Machivelli and risked sending betrayed Tory voters into a political wilderness.Mark Francois - who served as Conservative frontbencher for  years - told The Sun the Chequers plan looks like “some Machiavellian process or series of backstairs deals” that has “sought to overturn their clearly expressed decision”.And he said the political weather meant those Brexit-loving Tory voters would be left homeless and may never vote again.A study yesterday revealed that Brexit is already costing the public purse £m a week.The Centre for European Reform’s analysis found the UK economy is already .% smaller than it would have been had Remain won the referendum.But in an attempt at a Brexit boost, ministers announced that the UK will host a nationwide Festival of Britain  Northern Ireland in .FORMER Labour Minister Digby Jones warned pro-business Tories must unite as “Jeremy Corbyn is to wealth creation what Diane Abbott is to mathematics”.SCOTS Tory MP Ross Thomson savaged the one word conference slogan “OPPORTUNITY”, raging: “I couldn’t help thinking of the other words ‘missed’, ‘lost’, ‘wasted’ and ‘squandered’.”TRANSPORT boss Chris Grayling’s own train to Birmingham was late — but he was spotted passing the time playing FarmVille on his phone rather than working.FORMER Remainer Jeremy Hunt delighted the Leave-backing party faithful by comparing the EU to the Soviet Union and then channelling Maggie Thatcher by telling Brussels “no, no, no”.TORY Peter Bone said ex-Ukip boss Nigel Farage should be made a Lord and put in charge of Brexit, adding: “If he had been in charge, we would have been out by now.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: philip hammond brexit speech trevor kavanagh opinion
story: He is also writing his ­Halloween Budget on October . Nobody is hoping for voter-friendly treats.For a man in charge of our economic destiny at such a momentous time, this “stubby-pencilled accountant” has precious little to say. It seems he even remained mute at a recent Cabinet session to war-game a No-Deal Brexit — surely the Chancellor of the Exchequer’s special subject.Well-informed Spectator editor Fraser Nelson says other ministers piled in with upbeat projects but Hammond “seemed to have no ideas and kept quiet”. Spreadsheet Phil possesses either supreme self-confidence or total contempt for the .million who voted for Brexit, or both.The man who a year ago faced political death has become the most powerful figure in Theresa May’s Cabinet — perhaps including herself.She remains the figurehead. But the minister she planned to axe until her botched General Election is running the Brexit show from his Treasury eyrie.Hammond’s sympathetic image as Eeyore, a woebegone soft toy, is misleading. This man combines thin-skinned arrogance with a rare combination of political disabilities — cloth-eared, ham-fisted and leaden-footed.The grey image of bungled Budgets and barren creativity stands in vivid contrast to his outrageous Project Fear scaremongering. Mrs May certainly deserves blame for her hapless EU negotiations and the mutant Chequers plan for a Hi-HoBrexit.THE Tories have made a decent start to their conference – but they need to set their ambitions higher.Last week the Labour Party promised easy answers on everything from housing to the economy. It was a radical,utterly disastrous, vision for Britain.The Government changing tipping rules and increasing taxes on foreign property buyers is pretty small beer.Not least since the former was first announced three years ago and the latter is pretty much copied from last year’s Labour manesto.Philip Hammond — rarely mistaken for a ray of sunshine — needs to provide light at the end of the austerity tunnel.He must lay the groundwork for entrepreneurs to thrive in a newly liberated, unapologetically free market economy.And he should challenge business to work with him, too. The self-appointed “voices of British business”, iniably dominated by large corporate interests, push every day for more and more Brexit concessions.Yet as last week showed, Labour’s unreconstructed Marxism is a far more serious threat to future prosperity than any kind of Brexit.It’s time for big businesses to play their part in building a better Britain, rather than refighting a referendum which was as much a vote against them as the political establishment.Eeyore Hammond must encourage them to invest in Britain’s future.She survived last year’s election catastrophe only because Remainers feared a true Brexiteer such as Boris Johnson might replace her.Hammond has since deployed his Treasury reach to capitalise on her weakness and box us into BRINO — Brexit In Name Only. Mrs May is the willing captive of passionate Remainers in Downing Street, Whitehall, the Cabinet Office and, crucially, the all-powerful Treasury.Since the departure of close aide Nick Timothy, there is nobody within earshot who voted Brexit — including Mrs May. Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab, like his predecessor David Davis, has virtually no say in negotiations.Hammond now calls the shots, backed by panic-stirring Business Secretary Greg Clark and Europhile Cabinet Office minister David Lidington.Brexiteers fear this Unholy Trinity is ready for more concessions over issues including migration, EU benefits and Britain’s vital financial services industry.Never forget, it was Hammond who blocked all spending and therefore all serious preparation for No Deal, a prospect now apparently facing this nation. In fact there was never a chance of No Deal.We will end up with a form of Chequers, but one even more pro-Brussels than the proposal which saw David Davis and BoJo storm out. Remainers are back in full Project Fear mode.European car firms are happily pouring billions into Britain — despite Brexit. Yet Greg Clark triggered last week’s chorus of fake alarm from Toyota, claiming its “just-in-time” supply chain would grind to a halt.This ignores the whole point of “just-in-time”. It is designed specically to cope with delivery glitches and operates worldwide in all circumstances under global trade rules.It was also Clark who handed Brussels its biggest anti-Brexit card by promising those shroud-waving car giants the UK would remain under EU rules. That led directly to Mrs May’s surrender over the Northern Ireland border, which has plagued negotiations ever since.It is a tragic fact — but no surprise — that we are now heading remorselessly for a deal on EU terms at our expense.EU leaders were never going to see us thrive outside. They insisted we will not be better off after Brexit.Anyone who hoped we might be set free to compete on equal terms should read ex-Greek finance minister Yanis Varoufakis’ story of his own country’s punishment beating.It was Varoufakis who compared Brexit with the Eagles’ hit: “It’s like Hotel Calornia — you can check out any time you like, but you can never leave.” And we can blame Phil Hammond for blocking the fire Brexits.But Ms Jourova, a Czech raised under Soviet rule, wants Corbyn-style “regulation” of the free Press.The apple never falls far from the tree.PS. I wonder how M Macron feels after Europe’s Ryder Cup triumph in Paris... without a single French golfer And SIX from the UK!Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: bbc press doesnt get tabloids right
story: Theories have ranged from Keeley Hawes’ acting to Richard Madden’s arse, without considering a more obvious possibility.Every other competing drama was either too dull , too grim , or just too rubbish.Which brings me to Press, a series I’d wanted to avoid on the obvious grounds there was never any possibility I was going to like a BBC drama about tabloids.But what the hell. It was a quiet week, so I watched the first four episodes and, to my surprise and delight, I hated Press even more than I expected.The set-up’s the deal-breaker, of course. We’ve got a right-wing red-top called The Post, that’s very obviously meant to be The Sun, and a left-wing broadsheet The Herald, which is equally obviously , house Bible of the BBC.The former is edited by soul-selling clone Duncan Allen, played by the brilliant Ben Chaplin, who does actually resemble a couple of ex-colleagues.By rights then, the female lead should be The Herald’s editor, Amina Chaudury, played by Priyanga Burford.But she can’t act, so the responsibility’s fallen to Charlotte Riley as northern, working-class brick of Deputy News Editor Holly Evans, who fits the social profile of your averagewoman about as comfortably as Roy Chubby Brown fits a mankini.Next weird thing you probably notice about Press is that nearly all the characters are giving speeches, rather than talking normally to each other.Especially the insufferable broadsheet hacks, who never stop reminding each other “we speak the truth to the powerful”, and that “people buy The Herald for the truth”.Why do people buy The Post Sun It’s never really occurred to writer Mike “Doctor Foster” Bartlett, who clearly didn’t read our newspaper before he sat down to type Press, at his desk on the summit of Mount Olympus, and has probably never met a tabloid reader either, without telling them: “Keep the change.”How can I be so sure Because it’s got almost every single professional and technical aspect wrong, from Duncan’s insistence he’s going to do a spread “On page five and six” , to the week one headline The Post produced about the gay, blackmailed footballer who committed suicide: “Parents never knew their son.”Which is the sort of meaningless, esoteric b******s that would get thrown back at a student newspaper sub.That’s another unconvincing thing about Press, incidentally. No one swears. And I wouldn’t mind so muchthere were some decent stories to see us through, but there aren’t.There’s a Katie Hopkins figure floating around, a few cut-and-pasted bits of very old tabloid legendand some deep state conspiracy cobblers, which the BBC’s probably got written into Raa Raa The Noisy Lion these days.Duncan also has the vague hots for Holly, until such time as Ed off the newsdesk tells him she likes having it off in a grey vest.That’s about your lot, though.As always happens when British TV tries to dramatise the Press, the writer’s left-of-centre political agenda and prejudices trump everything .This is why Americans do it so much better, andyou want to see how newspapers really operate you’ll get a much better idea from Billy Wilder’s  film The Front Page than you ever will from Press.I’ll say this for the BBC production team though, they might not have much of an ear for newspaper dialogue, but they’ve got a hell of an eye for interior design and have duplicated one item of our office kitchen crockery perfectly.Mugs.“I don’t bend in the middle any more, to be honest.”Then just slap him around a bit.Improvise, woman.FURTHER proof,it were needed, there’s not a single television format that can’t be improved by the presence of one or two of the Happy Mondays arrived on Friday.A special BBC Music Day edition of Bargain Hunt, featuring Bez and Rowetta versus Pulp’s Jarvis Cocker and Candida Doyle, which will go down in daytime TV folklore.Attempting to keep them in some sort of order, at the Kent showground’s antique fair, was BH regular Charlie Ross, who didn’t get very far with his preliminary question: “How did it all start with the Happy Mondays, Bez ”“You really don’t want to know.”So you really couldn’t blame him for looking a bit nervous when he sent the pair of them away with £ in used notes.Half an hour later, though, Bez and Rowetta were back, with three items, including a biscuit tin and a to-die-for rustic, bygone horse collar mirror that’s yours for just  quid.It made them a respectable £ profit at auction, as well, and flattened Pulp’s efforts in the process.At which point things got a bit dark.Charlie noted “an irregularity”, the Mondays were hauled back on set, like guilty schoolkids, and the host was forced to explain that the winsome and very obliging woman at the back of the auction hall, who kept bidding for his items was in fact: “Bez’s girlfriend.”Not angry, Bez, just disappointed.IF you’ve never seen the brilliant Simpsons episode where Homer gives Pinchy, his pet lobster, a really hot bath, Google it as soon as you can.Then immediately after, watch Channel ’s darkly funny latest episode of Celebrity Island With Bear Grylls, where a pig wandered into camp, on Sunday night.Even more obligingly it then started fattening itself up on the celebs’ leftovers and inviting the obvious by crapping its load everywhere.While some sensed dinner, Towie’s Pete Wicks had a better idea.He named the pig Colin, took it for a walk and then tethered it with a rope to some rocks.Whereupon Colin, with the sort of demonic squeals and grunts you last heard on Deliverance, promptly strangled himself to death.Presented with this tragedy, you or I or Martin Kemp from Spandau Ballet, might’ve drawn the obvious conclusion and, like Homer Simpson, tucked in Not this lot.Instead Colin was buried at sea, with full military honours, to avoid “hurting Pete’s feelings”, floating off into the sunset like a warning to humanity.This MorningSemra Haksever: “I call myself an eclectic witch, so I take dferent little bits of magic from all over the place.So it’s all b******sOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: budget must put money in pockets
story: For all the wise words in his conference speech — on the opportunities of new technology, the horric dangers of Corbyn’s socialism and the importance of job-creating businesses — he needs answers to more immediate questions.The signs are ominous. The Chancellor, while admitting “st Century capitalism must deliver” for ordinary people, apparently intends to take MORE of our money for the NHS in his upcoming Budget.Polls apparently show voters are OK with that. But wait till it comes out of wage packets. Skint workers won’t thank the Tories for bailing out the health ­service. They’ll desert them for grabbing yet more of their take-home pay.Mr Hammond’s speech wasn’t all bad. His case against socialism was well put. Likewise his view that no sane party should try to outbid Corbyn’s ruinous spending pledges. We welcome his proposed digital services tax on Google and Facebookit can be made to work. ut Tory fortunes hinge on Brexit — and pay rises easily outstripping inflation.The Budget MUST put more money in pockets . . . not remove it with a tax raid or a suicidal rise in fuel duty.THE EU’s cry-bullies are OUTRAGED that Jeremy Hunt compared their aggression to the old Soviet Union. Well, diddums.He noted, quite reasonably, that Brussels’ forcible attempts to lock Britain in and deter others from leaving was ­reminiscent of the Soviet empire’s treatment of its member states.It is a figure of speech. The Foreign Secretary’s not literally comparing Juncker to Stalin’s regime of mass murder. And the EU has no defence. Which is why its lackeys, such as curtain-haired clown Guy Verhofstadt, instead wilfully misinterpreted him for dramatic effect.One even whined it could “damage relations” with other member states. Are they for real  The French president brands Brexit campaigners “liars” — implying .million Brits are dupes. Donald Tusk humiliates our PM. But WE’RE in danger of souring relations.Give it a rest, EU fools.HOW appalling that the sisters of terror victim cop Keith Palmer have no Legal Aid to pursue the truth at his inquest.Michelle Palmer and Angela Clark want to hire an independent expert to assess whether a permanent armed presence at Parliament’s Carriage Gates entrance might have saved their brother.But the Legal Aid Agency hasn’t processed their application. title: more young people are feeling lonely
story: The Eleanor Rigby of Beatles legend: “All the lonely people, where do they all come from ”An answer emerged this week — and they come from a surprising place.The loneliest people are healthy, thriving young adults, kicking off their career and probably renting a room in a city.According to new university research for the BBC, levels of loneliness are highest among  to -year-olds, with  per cent saying they often, or very often, feel it. In contrast, the over-s are positively chipper: Only  per cent of this group reported feelings of isolation.Now, I’m  and, depressingly, these statistics don’t surprise me.At first glance, it looks like young people have it easy when it comes to making friends.At  or thereabouts, more than  per cent of them will be packed off to university where they’ll move in with a group of like-minded people of the same age and be encouraged to drink and party like there’s no tomorrow.Which, when you’re only required to stumble out of bed for one pm lecture, there essentially isn’t.Rather than relying on friends of tenuous friends for dubious introductions, young people these days can simply download an app and get the details of thousands of eligible strangers delivered straight to their mobile phones.Add into the mix social media ­— which allows its users to connect with everyone they’ve ever met instantaneously at any given moment — and it’s hard to imagine how any young people could possibly be lonely, let alone  per cent.But there are two sides to every coin.University — though a godsend when it comes to meeting new people — can be a problem when it comes to staying in touch with them. Saddled with bottomless debt, young graduates simply don’t have the cash to socialise.When a round for six at a London pub will set you back  quid, is it any wonder that more and more young people are opting to stay at home Dating apps, too, come with their pitfalls. Yes, it’s nice to have a database of singletons in your pocket, but the ubiquity of Tinder and Bumble mean it’s now considered almost socially awkward to speak to someone you fancy in person.A friend of mine, who has absolutely no problem propositioning women on Tinder, hasn’t yet found the courage to ask for his next-door neighbour’s number, four months after she moved in.As for social media, young people like me are increasingly discovering that “staying connected” is a mixed blessing at best. With no excuse to lose touch, my generation holds on to friends we’ve outgrown, leaving us with no time to make new ones. It may sound callous, but there’s an art to shedding friends, and thanks to our social media addiction, we seem to have lost it.What’s more, earnest  to -year-olds seem to be taking to heart the faddish health advice that adults have been merrily ignoring for years, making it even harder for them to socialise because they fear alcohol, and even food.At the end of a recent party I got chatting to a fun young woman, so I suggested some pub grub at a boozer to round off the evening. How wrong I was.She explained in detail she was vegan and on a gluten-free diet , so the pub menu would not cater for her needs.I decided not to pursue it.So I say it’s time snowflake millennials took a bit of responsibility for their own feelings of isolation.Last month commentators wagged their fingers at the big tech companies after a survey by charity YoungMinds revealed a greater number of young people view social media as having a negative impact on the way they feel about themselves than those who report a positive impact.But it was never suggested depressed young people should simply put away their phones and do something .Mollycoddled millennials believe having a thriving social circle is a human right, rather than an ongoing project.Instead of popping to the pub for a pick-me-up with whoever happens to be around, a lonely young person will all too often turn to the internet for a spot of indulgent self-reflection, or to the gym for Insta-friendly self-improvement.As a result, pubs are closing at a rate of  a day, and sites such as Tumblr are overflowing with posters instructing users to “forget the haters” and “shine like the star that you are”.Of course, social media is made to be addictive. But surely putting down a phone can’t be an insurmountable challenge for an educated generation of young people  Dwelling on yourself is the surest route to a lonely lestyle, so instead of posting doleful, introspective memes on social media or clinging to tired old friendships, lonely young people should find the guts to get outside and look outwards.Making and keeping real friends takes work, and it’s time young people started putting the hours in.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: mystery ancient rock carvings indian hunter gatherer civilisation ancient
story: The incredible images were found hidden beneath the soil atop hillocks in the Konkan region of Maharashtra.Experts believe the carvings, known as petroglyohs, were created by a hunter-gatherer community - because many of the images are drawings of animals, reports the BBC.The discovery suggests the civilisation could have migrated to India from Africa, where many of the animals depicted are found.And the archaeologists believe the drawings may be the oldest petroglyphs ever found, possibly dating back to the year , BC.The etchings were found by a group of explorers led by Sudhir Risbood and Manoj Marathe, who began searching for the images in earnest after observing a few in the area. Many were found in village temples and played a part in local folklore.Mr Risbood told the BBC: We walked thousands of kilometres. People started sending photographs to us and we even enlisted schools in our efforts to find them. We made students ask their grandparents and other village eldersthey knew about any other engravings. This provided us with a lot of valuable information.The pair found petroglphs in and around  villages, but only about five of the communities were aware that the images existed.Tejas Garge, director of the Maharashtra state archaeology department, also told the BBC: We have not found any pictures of farming activities. But the images depict hunted animals and theres detailing of animal forms. So this man knew about animals and sea creatures. That indicates he was dependent on hunting for food.All kinds of animals, including sharks, whales and turtles feature in the carvings, while human figures and geometrical designs also appear.Since the remarkable discovery, the researchers have been working to document the thousands of ancient carvings and spur efforts to preserve them.The state government has designated  million rupees to study  of the petroglyphs in greater detail, according to the BBC.

title: kate middleton materinity leave visit forest school paddington rec
story: But the Duchess of Cambridge clearly had her own children on her mind as she greeted students at the forest school in Paddington, cooing over a seven-month-old almost the same age as my little boy.The mother has been on maternity leave for five months, with her visit to Paddington Recreation Ground her first official solo event since giving birth to Prince Louis in April.And today the -year-old was inundated with young fans, left beaming as a little girl rushed forward to hug her around her waist.Kate, clearly surprised, laughed as the girl gripped her arms around her waist, and a second rushed in to make it a royal group hug.The duchess, wearing a khaki green Fjällräven jacket, a silk Joseph and Penelope Chilvers shirt, and riding boots, is today visiting Sayers Croft Forest School and Wildle Garden to see how it is helping childrens emotional and physical well-being.It was a charming start to Kates first official solo event since welcoming third child Louis into the world.The duchess made sure to speak to as many students and families as possible as she was taken around the facility - drawn in by some of the younger kids at her welcome.Meeting a seven-month-old boy called Romi at the Paddington Recreation Ground, Kate gushed: He’s very chatty, he’s almost the same age as my little boy.Prince Williams we seemed happy to spend time with the young St Stephens school students, listening to story time with Monkey Queen, read to them by Sayers Croft forest school leader Jennie Miles.The royal, who was gted posies by four-year-old Janine, also helped to hand out cups of juice and papers to make crowns.And she was left in stitches as one student promised there would be no boring bits on the tour.The duchess replied: This is so cool, I cant wait to see it.The seasoned royals visit even closed her car door herself - title: car driving full tree branches stockport
story: His windscreen was obstructed and he couldnt reach the gear stick as he drove down Heaton Moor Road, Stockport.Police called the move absolute madness.PC Andy Monaghan said hed never seen anything like it and he had risked seriously injuring someone.The man in his s, who has not been named, had been doing gardening work for an elderly couple on September  and was taking the leafy branches to the tip when he was stopped by police.He decided to fill the blue Toyota Corolla to the brim with branches so he would only have to make one trip.But he was asked to empty his car in order to drive safely and then had to make multiple journeys to the tip to throw the branches away.He must now attend court accused of driving offences.PC Monaghan said: He thought hed be fine, but the weather was heavy and he had limited control.I wasnt shocked because Ive previously worked in traffic [but] it was absolute madness.

title: hounsdown school hampshire girls skirts distracting curvy figures
story: Ellie Porter and Jasmin Stacey, both , claim they were threatened with detention at Hounsdown School in Totton, Hampshire, and told their MS skirts should be shin .Ellies mum Gemma Porter claims one staff member suggested the skirts were inappropriate for curvy girls.She said she was horried the girls were being punished for their body shape because its out of their control.She said: [They] said our girls cant wear the skirts as theyre too close-fitting on them.[They] said its okay for girls with slender figures to wear the standard school skirt but its NOT okay for girls with curvy figures to wear it.Ms Porter claims the unorm issue came to light last month when Ellie ed to school after the summer break.She said she phoned the school to ask why the the skirt was deemed inappropriate - title: mark bristow randgold hunting elephant leopard south africa
story: Mark Bristow was photographed with several trophy kills including elephants, antelope, gazelle, a hippo, buffalo and a zebra taken in Africa.In promotional material dating from  to  he posed with a dead lion and leopard even though since  he has served on the conservation council of Panthera.The council  - dedicated to the welfare of wild cats - also includes actress Glenn Close as co-chairman, and actor Jeremy Irons.Bristow appears in promotional images on the website of Hunters  Guides Africa, a South Africa-based professional hunting tour operator.Mr Bristow, , who was born in South Africa but now lives in London, has been the CEO of mining giant Randgold since .The £bn company has a partnership with the Mali Elephant Project, which works to protect the worlds last remaining desert elephant herds.It is currently in the process of being bought by Canada’s Barrick  which will make it the world’s largest gold miner.Randgold told the : Legal, well-regulated hunting can and does deliver benefits for both wildle conservation and the livelihoods of indigenous communities living with wildle.Led by Mark Bristow, Randgold Resources has invested in a wide range of bioersity programmes in its host countries ... and is bringing together conservation professionals and scientists to develop a tailored method for the mining industry in Africa to restore the continent’s bioersity.However, the international wildle charity Born Free was far from impressed with the actions of Bristow - reported to be the longest serving FTSE  boss.Its president Will Travers said: “Mark Bristow is obviously fond of big numbers. His company, Randgold, just bought by Canada’s Barrick Gold, is worth at least £bn.But there are other numbers he may be less willing to discuss. Mr Bristow shoots African elephants – there are about , left.Mr Bristow shoots African hippo – there are about , left. He also shoots zebra, antelope, gazelle and leopard.He will claim that it supports conservation and development but evidence suggests that only around three per cent of what people like Mr Bristow spend on their deadly predilection ends up in ­local communities.“Trophy hunting is not illegal. title: theres something wrong with this penguin enclosure can you see what it is
story: The new attraction at Exotic Zoo in Telford, Shrops., cost tens of thousands of pounds to build and had been hotly anticipated - but can you see what was wrong with it The enclosure is filled exclusively with model penguins because zoo owners couldnt get the real thing.A delivery of six Humboldt penguins was expected this July but the zoo was unable to get any due to an outbreak of avian malaria.So instead they put plastic figurines in as the enclosure is too specialist to house any other animals.Zoo director Scott Adams took the decision to use the models until they can get actual penguins. Scott said: Weve just timed it really badly.The enclosure is the zoos most expensive to date and we had hoped to have it open for the start of the summer holidays. But then disaster struck.Because of the outbreak of penguin malaria we were unable to get hold of three pairs we had been planning to get in for visitors to enjoy.Instead weve had to use le-size models of ious dferent species of penguins so we can at least educate visitors to an extent.Scott said that avain malaria had been catastrophic for penguins in the UK.He said: Lots of zoos,not most zoos, have lost a lot of penguins and in some case most of their stock.The zoos even planning to dress a member of his staff in a penguin costume over the Christmas period as he doesnt believe the problem will be rectied until the new year.But theres no prospect of any real penguins arriving at Exotic Zoo until next year.People visiting the zoo huddled together in their disappointment.Julie Fearn, , of Shrewsbury, said: It does look a bit weird and its a little bit disappointing because it would be lovely to see the penguins.Dad-of-one Paul Lawley of Telford, added: Its a shame theyve spent all this money and got nothing to show for it. Its really sad news about the penguins dying too.But I would have just left it emptyI was them. It looks like the Madame Tussauds version of a zoo.

story: DUP boss Arlene Foster said she would never accept a Brexit deal that brought in any new dferences in trade rules between Northern Ireland and the rest of the UK.She laid down the gauntlet barely  hours after it emerged the PM is plotting to offer the EU dferent regulatory rules for Northern Ireland as a Brexit insurance backstop.Ms Foster told The Sun: “No, no, no. story: Cyclone Leslie has been gathering strength after being spotted  miles east Bermuda but could perform a dramatic U-turn and head towards Britain.The US National Hurricane Center today said the storm has a max sustained speed of mph while it heads towards the east coast of America.Met Office forecaster Richard Miles told The Sun Online: “Storm Leslie is heading towards the east coast of the US at the moment but it will turn eastwards.“It will take an eastwards trajectory across the Atlantic in the middle of next week and will turn towards Europe.“We don’t know where it will end up, though - it’s too soon to say. It will definitely follow an eastwards path towards Britain but it’s too early to say where it will hit.”The National Hurricane Center, based in Miami, Florida, said the winds caused by the storm could cause le-threatening surf and rip currents.A spokesman said: “Large swells generated by Leslie will continue to affect portions of the southeastern coast of the United States, Bermuda, and the Bahamas.“These swells could cause le-threatening surf and rip currents.“Although the swells are forecast to abate temporarily in the Bahamas later today, they are expected to increase again on Wednesday and Thursday, and propagate farther southward into the Greater and Lesser Antilles.The spokesman added that the storm will move “northeastward” and will “meander” over the central Atlantic for the rest of this week.

title: snake found inside oven by oap cooking chips
story: The African brown house snake had slithered into the elderly couple’s home on Macclesfield Road in Hazel Grove, Stockport.They called the RSPCA and an inspector was sent to their home. Initially he couldn’t find the runaway reptile, but it eventually turned up again two days later on September .Fortunately, the couple were animal lovers and were concerned for the welfare of the non-venomous snake, although they admitted the bizarre discovery put them off their chippy tea.The woman, who did not want to be named, said: “When I opened the oven door and saw it for the first time I got the shock of my le.“I have recently had a cataract operation and was wonderingmy eyes were deceiving me - but my husband saw it too.“We are big animal lovers and just wanted to make sure the snake was safe so we were pleased that he was rescued by the RSPCA.“I gave the inspector a big hug and a cup of tea afterwards but I went off the idea of oven chips so sent my husband to the fish and chip shop instead!”It is not knownthe snake is male or female at this stage so it has been given the unisex name Sammy by a reptile keeper who will now care for it.Inspector Andy Harris was called to the scene and was surprised to see the size of the snake.He said: “When I arrived I expected to find a small snake but this one was quite long - at least three foot.“I managed to coax the snake from the oven and was able to safely get hold of it with specialist equipment and then contain it securely.“The snake is an African brown house snake, which is a non-venomous species, so I suspect that he is a pet that has escaped or been abandoned.“It must have squeezed through a wall cavity of this couple’s home and there is a hole at the back of the oven where the gas jets come up so was probably attracted by the warmth.“It was lucky the couple didn’t pre-heat the oven first.”This species of snake is often very nervous, but is not prone to biting.They are frequently found in and around human dwellings in Africa, where they consume rodents, small lizards, and even birds.Many of the snakes that the RSPCA’s officers are called to collect are thought to be escaped pets.The RSPCA recommends owners invest in an enclosure suitable for the particular species and that it is kept securewhen unattended to prevent accidental escape.The RSPCA advises anyone who sees a stray exotic snake to keep a safe distance, call the helpline on    and monitor the animal until inspectors arrive.

title: why people put sellotape on keyholes
story: Homes in Dublin have been the latest targets of this chilling trick, with at least two properties in the same street being targeted.According to one resident, who spoke to the Irish Independent: “It’s a tactic they use.“They cover the keyhole with clear sellotape to establishthe house is being accessed.“Two houses were found to have this tape on my street recently in North Strand. This is deeply concerning for residents.”Locals claim the same trick has also been adopted by squatters looking for vacant homes to take over.They have now asked for additional patrols of the area with police looking into the matter seriously.Residents have been advised to remove any tape they see immediately to prevent making themselves targets.Dublin City Councillor Ciaran Cuffe confirmed reports of similar incidents over the past months.He said: It can be a way of determining whether a building is in use.I could see it being used for sinister uses like burglary, or there may be other reasons.The councillor added there were a number of vacant properties in his constituency but noted that this was the case “for the right reasons”, including people away on holidays or a recent death.The rise of the sellotape trick is the latest in a string of concerns for Irish homeowners.Last year residents noticed odd road marking appearing on footpaths in the Ballybrack and Shankill areas of Dublin.It is believed these were also used by burglars to target homes as they had not been installed by the local council.Elsewhere, similar markings were popping up in Clonaslee, County Laois, after farmers homes began being targeted with stone mounds and markings alerting burglars to “valuable properties.”
